Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A large container is filled with water. The container is filled to a height <math alttext="uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A release valve is opened at a height <math alttext="lowercase d" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> above the floor, and water exits horizontally from the valve, and initially hits the floor a distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> from the side of the container. Assume the water in the container is still. The effects of friction, turbulence, and viscosity are negligible.
content.question:
(a)

i. Derive an expression for the speed of the water <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> leaving the valve in terms of <math alttext="uppercase D" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, <math alttext="lowercase d" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>, and physical constants as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference book.

(a)

i. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference book.

ii. Derive an expression for the horizontal distance <math display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> traveled by the water before hitting the floor in terms of <math alttext="uppercase D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, <math alttext="lowercase d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>, and physical constants as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference book.

iii. When the container is filled to a height <math alttext="uppercase D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math>, the speed of the water exiting the valve is <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. On the axis provided, sketch a graph of the speed of the water leaving the valve as a function of the height of the water in the container.

(b) Suppose that the container is filled with salt water which has a greater density than fresh water. How will this change affect the horizontal distance <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> traveled by the water before it reaches the floor? Justify your response beyond derivations or referencing equations.
